+Felix Coeln the rule of 70 is just a way to ballpark the time, you are 
basically assuming linearity when in reality it is logarithmic, but because 
logarithms grows so slow, it is close enough near the beginning to get a 
good estimate. For instance, if you were to invest $100 with compounding 
interest at a rate of 9% per annum, the rule of 70 gives 70/9 = 7.78 years 
required for the investment to be worth $200; an exact calculation gives 
ln(2)/ln(1+.09) = 8.0432 years.

How can mathematicians converge on an answer? The answer will differ based 
on what the final digit is. If it is -1, then the answer will be 0 (and 1-s 
will give you 1), and if the final digit is +1, then the answer will be 1 
(and 1-s will be 0). If someone were to graph this, it would be a sine wave 
with y-axis being the final answer and x-axis denoting the number of terms 
in the function. If you choose x-axis to be the actual numbers (1 or -1), 
then you would get an oscillation between (1,1) and (-1,0). The final 
answer (y value) would be a 1/2 when x=0, but in this series of 1s and -1s, 
there is no 0.﻿

comments.text:
the concept of infinite sums is abstract, there is not a finite value, 
there is not an "end" answer. The best answer would be to say it's 
ambiguous, you're trying to attain an exact value to something that 
represents an infinite amount of terms. Infinity is not a number, that's 
why it's abstract, there fundamentally cannot be a numerical answer to 
infinity. The purpose of it is to find out what's happening between, like 
*approximately* how long the light has been on or off in two minutes using 
that series to some amount of accuracy. You cannot get an exact value, but 
you can get very, very, very close, that's the purpose of this. Trying to 
find out what happens at the end of something endless is literally 
impossible.﻿
comments.author: SoulxReaper366

comments.text:
I'm surprised that the most intuitive "proof" wasn't shown here.  The sum 
of an infinite geometric series (whose first term is 1) is: 1/(1 - r), 
where r is the common multiple.  Thus 1 + 1/2 + 1/4 + 1/8 + 1/16 + .... = 
1/(1 - 1/2) = 1/(1/2) = 2.

You can apply the same idea to Grandi's Series.  Here, the first term is 1 
and the common multiple (r) is clearly -1.  Therefore, sum = 1/(1 - (-1)) = 
1/2.  Wouldn't this approach work as well?﻿
comments.author: John David (NicholasOfAutrecourt)

comments.text:
+John David No, it wouldn't. The formula for an infinite geometric series a 
+ ar + ar^2 + ar^3 + ar^4 + ... = a/(1 - r) only works when the modulus of 
r is less than 1, or -1 < r < 1. The r in the Grandi's Series is -1 which 
does not fit the requirement therefore the infinite sum formula can't be 
used.

comments.text:
+arnie365 Well, we are interested with the number the series converges to. 
That's what the dots mean.But actually, there is four different series: 
sum( (-1)^(k)) from k=1 to infinity. It can be proven that this series 
doesn't converge. There is no "answer", this sum isn't equal to a number.
A different, but similar looking sum is sum((1-1)) from k=1 to infinity. 
This sum has the same number of 1 and -1 for every k and thus is equal to 
0. We always have an even number of summands.
Another sum is sum((1-1)) from k=1 to infinity -1. We have an uneven number 
of summands and for every k an excess -1. The result is -1.
And the final one 1 + sum(-1+1) from k=1 to infinity. Also uneven number of 
summands, with an excess 1. The limit is one.
Keep in mind that we are interested in the limit. An infinite sum is 
defined mathematically in a way such that it is equal to its limit, if it 
has one. It is not relevant that it "does not stop".

comments.text:
The summation of an alternating series (the sum of (-1)^n x a-sub-n from 
n=1 to infinity) doesn't converge if the limit of a-sub-n as n approaches 
infinity isn't less than 1. In the example in this video, the limit of 
a-sub-n as n approaches infinity is 1, thus it the sum of all of these 1's 
and negative 1's diverges. It doesn't approach any number; not 1, not 0, 
not one half. The sum is indeterminate. Don't believe me? Go research the 
basics of infinite sequences and series.﻿

I see it more like a probability or an expectation. If someone is to walk 
into a room and pick which set of brackets to start with, without any prior 
preconceived notions of which one is correct, each choice will be equally 
probable. Therefore the probability of (choosing) one of the two is 1/2 
each. Therefore the expectation is 0*(1/2) + 1*(1/2), or (0+1)/2 = 1/2 to 
an observer who views the answer as the number of views goes to infinity. 
Even if we were to include the third series that has a sum of 1/2 and then 
plug into into our expectation, with a probability that each series is 
equally likely, the probability will be 1/3 so we still get (0+1+1/2)/3 = 
1.5/3 = 1/2. To the answer of the light switching problem, I think at the 
end we will see a room which is half lit as we will not be able to 
distinguish on from off as the interval between each light state will 
become too small to see.﻿
